/COMMIT_MSG.message:
i dont understand what it means, could you explain?

keepalived will bind the VIP to the defined interface, the master/backup is to negotiate which instance will handle the VIP as master. Setting it to master will say that all nodes are masters, while doing to backup, it says all are backups so decide which one is master based on the priority.

Whats the issue you seeing in the behavior?

keepalived always negotiate through priority, mostly the state option is informative,even set to master/backup will negotiate anyway. The state is just for the first installation.

We already changed the behavior to avoid two VIP flips https://review.openstack.org/#/c/292184/

If the master is down, VIP is moved to slave, when master is up, VIP is moved again to master, thats the reason of the nopreempt:

From keepalived manpages:

# VRRP will normally preempt a lower priority # machine when a higher priority machine comes # online. "nopreempt" allows the lower priority # machine to maintain the master role, even when # a higher priority machine comes back online. # NOTE: For this to work, the initial state of this # entry must be BACKUP. nopreempt

Currently,we only have one keepalived.conf.j2 template, so it can only be set as either slave or master, if set it to slave, keepalived cannot automatically negotiate master through priority, but when set it to master,keepalived can  negotiate a master ,if the master node  process is down，the other node will keep the vip ，and when the process is recover，the vip will back  . I have already tested it several times.

specs/no-secrets.rst.message: Despite the general resistance to no_log, I (and I'd guess kolla in general) am definitely +1 to the idea of not displaying secrets - thanks for raising.

I don't think anyone's ok with it, but perhaps your environment makes it more of an issue than it is for others.  I can't speak for others, but I tend to run tasks manually in production right now, and don't store logs anywhere public. It's not ideal and we're looking at other ways to do things.

I think the issue is that the alternatives in general aren't difficult to investigate, so why not spend a little time on them rather than bungling in the first idea that comes to mind.

Ah, 'I tend to run tasks manually in production right now', don't do it man :)

Fair point on the alternatives though, will adjust this spec as I get back to work this week.

Ya, honestly the amount of resistance to no_log as a 'stop the hemorrhaging' approach is sort of baffling; it's like people are ok with hemorrhaging (I am not); thus why my suggestion for even the brute-force `no_log` is an improvement (I'd rather have a safe system that is a little hard to debug for some time then leaking secrets all over the place).
Problems to better

I think that would definitely help - perhaps a catalogue of the types (not instances) of violations observed in the problem description would clarify things.

no_log for ansible module_args is a better solution. 

On the other hand, kolla uses lots of command modules, which is hard to avoid spewing out password. So one possible solution is convert the command module to a custom python module.

I've suggested using this on a number of your submissions:

loop_control:
  label: <something safe>

It allows for a different representation of the item being looped over than a simple print. It allows for a much cleaner output when the items are large/complex and also allows you to remove any undesirable fields from the output.

I'd at least like this listed as an alternative, and ideally investigated if adding no_log to module arguments does not whack all (or any of) the moles.

For example with the libfreetype6 dependency described above we would install "libfreetype-dev" and "libfreetype6-dev" into the rootfs if we did not make use of the base-build.lst to describe these as build only dependencies."
Yeah, positive comments make it more reasonable.

I think this update is going about this backwards.  Rather than trying to list the packages that are 'build dependency only', you should be identifying the list of packages that need to be included in the iso.

Note:  The iso list need not be exhaustive, just the top line services.  Additional packages should be added to satisfy those named in the iso list.

That is difficult for one people to maintain the iso list. For example, the libfreetype6 and libfreetype6-dev is not installed into iso, and at least no issue is found so far. Due to a build dependence issue, we have to add them into iso list, which will increase the image size. 

The alternative is submitting an empty base-buid.lst for this review. After that, only adding the special build dependencies which are not in Debian snapshot, when it is necessary. Does it make sense?
Scott, how about an empty base-build.lst only to add the binaries needed during build and these binaries aren't in Debian bullseye.

I also heard a requirement to add kubernetes 1.24 (and newer) which requires golang 1.18.5 and a bunch of newer than 'bullseye' packages, most of which are only in Debian next release "Bookworm". It shouldn't add all the packages into base-bullseye.lst. I think it is needed to introduce a new place to store some packages are only for build purpose, and the packages are not in current Debian release.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> Can we just lift the version cap?  Normally we try to use uncapped versions so that we get updates automatically and then put in caps temporarily if something breaks.  (The current < cap is an indication that we dropped the ball on that.)

I'm fine to do that if that's what's preferred from a project standpoint. 

For context, typically I avoid having ambiguous version numbers for imports because it results in less predictable build artifacts even for the same commit hash.  eg: with the version locked here I know that any image built from this will always have the expected version, which makes debugging easier later.

Yeah, I think this would match most closely what we're doing elsewhere, so I'd like to try that.  I totally get the locking versions argument, and I think that's a perfectly legit thing for a downstream consumer to want to do.  From an upstream project standpoint, we try to roll with the latest of everything, continuously, except when it breaks (which it does, quite often, and we take joy in how quickly we become aware of such problems).
sure. sounds good to me
I don't mind keeping the upper bound, but it sounded like you meant to remove it.

There should be no cap at all.  The only time we will add an upper version is when we know it won't work, and that is temporary.  There is no "qualification" process other than the test failure that will occur the next time we try to propose a change.  That is how we handle *all* python dependencies in the zuul project.

To clarify in plain language, are we wanting to have the upper bound mean 'we support any 1.35 or less version' or is it ok to say 'we support 1.35.x up to 1.35.6, but have not qualified >.7'? I'm ok with either option.
Sure.  As I think about it, this probably does need a minimum bound though as it'll be broken with earlier version

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This is a bit of an odd one given this is already constrained in upper-constraints: https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/stable/wallaby/upper-constraints.txt#L586

> This is a bit of an odd one given this is already constrained in upper-constraints: https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/stable/wallaby/upper-constraints.txt#L586

Hey Michael, this is unfortunately a kind of broken-design of tox why the `requires` option is necessary.

When calling tox, it first creates virtual environment with most recent virtualenv package by default and ignores the constraints (as those are only defined for the dependencies really). Then, when the actual deps are installed, they use wrong setuptools that was installed with virtualenv.

To make the constraints for setuptools effective, the install_command would have to be changed to always downgrade the setuptools first and then install what's specified in requirements.txt file.

NOTE: the problem may not be visible in OpenDev Zuul instance, as the Zuul jobs here do not build the packages, but use the prebuilt wheels from some mirros instead (at least from what I checked).

I believe this is a very similar situation to the use_2to3 issue that was discussed on openstack-discuss in September 2021 [1], and the thread indicated pretty devent community support for pinning versions in ways similar to this change.  That support came at least partially because (quoting from the thread): "Zuul's ensure-tox task[4] installs tox which installs the virtualenv package which bundles the latest setuptools package. This happens without applying any constraints."

[1] https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-September/024987.html
[4] dangling reference from the quote.
Yeah, these stable branches here do not have any test failures as they enforce those upper constraints limits. That is why I commented that also pinning this in tox is a bit odd.
Amended the commit message to make it clear that it is not issues with the upstream CI being remediated by this change.

Not liking any of these solutions, my preferred path would be to drop the unsupported akamai backend.

Could you add a sentence describing what the external system can achieve with this synchronization? Is it so that the external system can stop the nova actions before they start consuming hypervisor resources so that the external system can bring up CPUs then notify nova to proceed consuming them?

How this will work together with the reserved value of the VCPU and PCPU resource in placement? If the external system keeps the offline resources reserved then nova scheduling will not select those resources so no waiting will ever triggered for those resources to bring them up. Or are these two use case (reserved value - offline CPU, and waiting for external sync) are separate?

yes, the intent would be to allow the external system to online the CPUs that were selected by nova before it invokes libvirt.

the other case that is more immediate is allowing you to set the cpu governor and or frequency before the VM starts.

regarding scheduling, I was not sure how open upstream would be to the external event and synchronization.

if we have the event we do not need to update reserved as we can online the cores before the VM starts
if we don't have it then we need to do the placement management.

I guess I would have the arbiterd disable the placement reservation management when the events when the notification was enabled and only allow it to dynamically offline CPUs when it's available.

if we do not have the notification the intended use case was the admin would do "systemctl enable arbiterd" to offline CPUs statically and to allow new workloads they would do "systemctl disabled arbiterd"

at least in the initial version that has no interaction with nova notifications system.

that breaks down if we want to add the ability to manage cpu frequency via userspace governor as arbiterd or any external management application like RMD would have to run to introspect change to guest metadata.
so the workflow would likely be more like updating the external agent's config file or touching a file 
/run/arbiterd/arbitrate-cpu-state and deleting it to deactivate it.


I have presented this in 3 steps because each step enables more functionality.

if we have step one only then we can offline the CPUs and update the cpu governor asynchronously.
without the ability to update the reserved state in placement we can either disable the service or
create an allocation to get the correct scheduling behavior.

if we also do step 2 we can manage the reserved state which is a little cleaner.
if we do step 3 technically we don't need step 2 it just is more invasive of a change to nova but it is what I think would be most useful long term.

what are your thoughts on step 2 (reserved value) and step 3 external event and notification?
I probably call this cpu-external-management-complete if it is cpu specific, or hypervisor-external-management-complete if it is not.
Ack
That make sense.

If this feature is configured certain nova operations takes an extra REST API call (the external-event-arrival) to complete. This could increase load on the REST API as well as the message bus in a busy system. 

Still this feature is opt-in so I'm not worried. The operators enabling this should measure the performance hit and dimension accordingly.

ack that is a valid point i can call that out here.
but yes its intended to be opt in and presumable the operator could extend any timeouts or plan for the extra load.

one additional even in principal should not be a large load but it still worth capturing.

The external event handling is virt driver agnostic but this event is virt driver specific. We need a logic between compute manage and virt driver so that the compute manager knows when to wait for the external-events. 

Also other in tree virt driver developers can optionally implement the support for the same logic in the respective virt driver
+1, I think the external event should be virt-driver agnostic, meaning ideally this should be the compute service and not the driver which should be responsible for emitting it.

ack yes so perhaps the config option for the event should really be in the compute section.
then we can keep this outside of the virt driver.

I'm wondering if tempest test can be done with a small noop daemon that listens to nova notifications and triggers the external event without doing anything on the hypervisor. This would create a nice template for daemon developers how to create their own logic.

yep, it likely could. I could also see just adding a dry run mode to arbiterd or similar.
I could explore doing this also in the nova tree via a nova devstack plugin
it would be simple to add a nova console script entry point that would just listen on the notification bus and respond with the external event. ill add that to the spec.

I do plan to provide an arbiterd devstack plugin and eventually upstream that to opendev.

adding 3.6 support would not be hard I just don't want to use the old APIs right now.

As we discussed during today CI meeting, I think this needs some extra cleaning of the old neutron-keepalived-state-change processes which may be running for existing routers already.

NOTE: about the concern raised during the CI meeting about this patch and the upgrade process. A system can have a running keepalived-state-change process, spawned before the L3 agent update. The new L3 agent will keep them running. To kill them, the "ProcessManager" instance will use the PID stored in the PID file (that is in the same place for both scripts). Then it will send a SIGTERM or SIGKILL signal over this process. The next time the script is spawned, it will be the new one.

tempest/config.py.message:
I have a question about this. Technically there is project scope and domain scope: https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/contributor/services.html

Keystone defines scope pretty openly. Nova in the spec also says scope can be "project" or "system": https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ussuri/implemented/policy-defaults-refresh.html#scope

So should this be enforce_system_scope because that is what you are using it for? I don't think this will ever be used for domain scoping or anything.

actually, this flag is for - if service enabled the CONF.oslo_policy.enforce_scope then we have to pass the appropriate scope (for nova case it is project or system). If CONF.oslo_policy.enforce_scope is True on any service side then oslo policy will start enforcing the scope checks. So in Tempest if this flag (which is corresponding to CONF.oslo_policy.enforce_scope) is true then we should pass credential corresponding to the policy default scope which can be project or system or domain.
Same question: Should this say "system scope" instead?

ironic/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
tl;dr query.all basically would do the following:
1) retreive raw sql response
2) convert response into a tuple
3) Map field order into an SQLAlchemy response object
4) subquery/deduplicate and so on and so forth
5) convert the response to an modeled object based upon the query.

We would then convert the object into a dict like object for our ironic objects.

Internally under the hood, deduplicate is gone as the programmer invokes it now if needed, and I believe it goes from 1->3 which is now a hybrid dict-like object, to 4, and then hands back a tuple on the response type.

Overall, in the grand scheme of the universe, this is likely small potatoes even if it is in net negative territory.

off-topic: But also, this method seems to have been missed shrinking! At first glance I don't see why we do not report progress for shrinking (which is pretty similar to sharding - in both cases we are cleaving shard ranges in order). Should it actually be:

PITA but should probably check epoch is not None, see sharder.py line 1166:

  # epoch is reset to None, and state set to ACTIVE (like re-defaulted)
Done

osr.epoch can apparently be None in tests

	sharder-test ERROR: Unhandled exception while dumping progress for /mnt/tmp/tmp42yq622r/sdb/containers/0/ash/c1hash/c1hash.db: float() argument must be a string or a real number, not 'NoneType': 
	Traceback (most recent call last):
	  File "/home/vagrant/swift/swift/container/sharder.py", line 2252, in _one_shard_cycle
	    self._record_sharding_progress(broker, node, error)
	  File "/home/vagrant/swift/swift/container/sharder.py", line 933, in _record_sharding_progress
	    and (float(own_shard_range.epoch) +
Done

This IS in essence what we're worried about, so the message is fine, 

...but being pedantic, there is no requirement that epoch equals the time at which the own_shard_range was merged into the container DB, which predicates sharding starting. (s-m-s-r and auto-sharding DO set epoch and then merge, but someone could do it differently).

So it is possible that this warning would fire "too soon" if epoch was chosen to be in the past w.r.t when the shard ranges got merged and sharding actually began.

If we really cared, we could extend CleavingContext and embed the actual time the cleaving context was created in the context, and use that value to monitor progress. But I'm not sure I do care enough to add that work!

Instead, the warning could be just boringly factual:

  'Sharding has not completed in %f seconds since epoch' % (now - epoch)
Done

But that is way off-topic for this patch!

here and below in the Warning log we use the verb 'sharding' when the action could be 'sharding' or 'shrinking'. Strictly, the coomon verb for both actions is 'cleaving'. But there is plenty of ambiguity in the code: originally the sharder only sharded, and cleaving was only a shrading primitive. But when we added shrinking support and realised that shrinking would re-use the sharder's cleaving primitives, then the confusion arose.

Both sharding and shrinking DBs 'shard' (or 'cleave') themselves into shards!

I'm inclined to live with the ambiguity for now since we do so little shrinking.
thanks for the explanation.

we could differentiate shrinking vs sharding but actually it is helpful to have only one warning log to pattern match for an alert, and the message includes the own shard range state which *does* differentiate.

If we were to change this verb I would advocate using 'Cleaving', but I'm not sure it's necessary.
Let's change it to 'Cleaving', now I have same feeling as yours.
this is the significant new part

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Is this the right way to restart slapd if slapd is managed by sm?
I think so, because sm will take over and manage services at the very end of unlock. (at this moment sm is not managing this service).

Since this is a second unlock, so to speak, second to the one done at install, the slapd was under sm control, here it is just restarted. When I do manual restart of slapd, I first do a "sm-unmanage service open-ldap".

The restart has a onlyif condition. The second unlock after the initial one, the slapd.conf has already moved to slapd.conf.backup. The restart won't be even executed.(since it's not neccessary, the exec before it "-> Exec['slapd-convert-config']" is skipped for the same reason, so nothing change to require a restart)
Should the stop be chained (->)  to the restart?
Yes, they are chained on line 127 and 131.

> However, removing the * is not sufficient either. I need both to remove the * here and use patch 860472

The above is not the right fix however. I got some feedback from slagle:

- /var/lib/kolla/config_files/src-iscsid/ is not to be created on the host
- the "source" is telling kolla-start where to read from inside the container
- /var/lib/kolla/config_files on the host is for the kolla configuration files
- short term fix is probably to comment out that whole key for now (lines 14-17)
- long term fix is to make iscsid role actually generate a config file. then we could leave the glob, which is what we want

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This seems to handle several serial numbers. Is it really the case? Your commit message suggests we just need another source of serial numbers, which could be lsblk. Does lsblk list serial numbers in your case?
Ack
Done

There was one incident where lsblk had the correct number for a SCSI device but then there was a situation where lsblk also had the wrong value as far as I can recall. 

My logic was to check all the serial numbers in case the defaults don't work to have the highest chance to find the correct device.

> We could do both actually, I could modify it in a way that lsblk would be the primary source of truth and the udev serials would be the fallback values

I'd suggest we start with this. Several values seems like a corner case that should be fixed in the base OS.

I don't have enough data to say that lsblk is always correct either 😂. The issue with uedv is also not consistent. For some device it appers with a certain udev+kernel for some it happens with a newer udev+kernel.

quickstart.sh.message: This will pull the latest code from aoc's ACO_BRANCH branch and not what is checked out in the aoc repo, thus e.g. breaking our tripleo jobs in aoc.

This will pull the latest code from ACO_BRANCH and this will then shadow the aoc rpm which gets installed later (*). So our tripleo ci jobs will not test whether the rpm is working, instead it will test whether the latest code in aoc upstream is working with rdo.

(*) ansible-galaxy collection install will install aoc to ~/.ansible/collections which is preferred by ansible over the /usr/... path where rdo rpms gets installed.

Though I think tripleoclient won't use the galaxy installed rpms in  $VIRTUAL_ENV/share/ansible/collections, I've pushed a WIP patch[1] to avoid using ~/.ansible as well, let's see.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/861354

> ansible-galaxy collection install will install aoc to ~/.ansible/collections

Isn't -p option to provide the location of install. Also, can we not override COLLECTIONS_PATHS to use collections from specific locations?

Btw, There is only one instance of direct AOC module usage in tq/tqe, though the os_tempest role used for tempest uses a few of them too[1]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/src/branch/master/tasks/tempest_resources.yml#L180

The reason why role os_tempest is not using the RPM is that the role is run by the Ansible instance that quickstart starts [1],[2]. When this instance is started, collections used by this instance have to be available.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/src/commit/048667a14d20278266a17f7e1f5e23bc74157aac/playbooks/quickstart-extras-validate.yml#L24
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/src/commit/048667a14d20278266a17f7e1f5e23bc74157aac/playbooks/tasks/tempest.yml#L275

From https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/+/861278 failures I can see that tq/tqe use the collections installed from galaxy in the workspace and not from the rpm. So not sure why this will break anything and why?

Yes, Ansible will use the OpenStack collection (AOC) from Galaxy and ignore the RPM. This means, the jobs will test TripleO deployments against Galaxy releases but not against RDO's RPMs for AOC. RDO users and downstream releases dont use quickstart, so they will use e.g. the RPMs. Since we dont test the RPMs in our CI, we dont know whether they actually work.

This is not a new issue though. So far, we pinned the AOC release we pull from Galaxy to the exact same version that Alfredo packages in RDO in order to get the same content. This is not maintainable though, we already drifted apart, i.e. RDO has AOC 1.9.1 while quickstart still has 1.8.0.

We thought about overriding COLLECTIONS_PATHS but one thing we have to clarify here first is that the Ansible instance that quickstart launches is NOT the same Ansible instance that deploys TripleO, else COLLECTIONS_PATHS wont have any positive effect.
Rabi, maybe you can give us some insights here? Or point us to code where we can check that or point us to someone we could ask?
Also I think tripleoclient is using rpm collections with this patch and not the galaxy installed ones in CI.

Went down the rabbit hole...

Job tripleo-ci-centos-9-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001 [1] uses Ansible's shell module for 'undercloud install' [2].

Job tripleo-ci-centos-9-standalone [3] uses Ansible's shell module for 'Standalone deploy' [4].

Ansible's shell module is actually a action plugin [5] which calls Ansible's command module [6] which then calls Ansible's run_command function from the AnsibleModule base class [7]. This run_command will use the environment variables of the Ansible instance running this module and uses them for the actual shell execution [8].

Defining Ansible's ANSIBLE_COLLECTIONS_PATHS variable will (probably) passed down to the TripleO deployment commands. But will it be passed further down to the Ansible instances later in the deployment process? Somebody more familiar with TripleO will have to answer.

In case it is, we definitely want to modify ANSIBLE_COLLECTIONS_PATHS in later tripleo stages.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I need this working to land some fixes... 😭

I did some local testing; it looks like this will proactively migrate DBs to this encoding (good!). 

This can have some side effects; so I suggest we put in an upgrade release note warning of this migration - it should be free in most cases but being explicit about it is not a bad idea.

I think this is fine with a bigger release note.

So, I don't like this change. I don't think I'll like any change that solves this problem though, so I don't think that matters.

The -1 is for this specific case: what happens if an operator has already deployed Ironic on a DB that is set to utf8mb4 -- won't all our existing (and future) migrations break those users pretty aggressively?

I'm not sure how we get out of this without forcing a hard migration for *someone*, but being explicit about encoding in our migrations, when we haven't before, is likely to put an operator in a position where something is broken in a difficult-to-fix way that may have otherwise been unpredictable.

In fact, I'm fairly sure that today, if an operator performed these steps; they'd likely be broken already:
- Dump ironic DB without create table statements (a valid way to dump/backup DBs)
- Run ironic DB creation tool on a new DB that's running *newer* mysql/mariadb/etc
- Import your DB
- Operator finds out, after the fact, values are truncated.



I think this attempt to solve this ... DB mismatch quietly is laudable; but we're better off making loud noises and requiring operators to manually validate or migrate than just changing these out from under them. Essentially we have a minefield of operator DBs out there, waiting to blow up when/if exported from their existing DB server into a new one.

manila/share/api.py.message:
Just want to call the attention to this reservation. In order to allocate these quotas in the new share-type, we need to allocate 'shares' and 'gigabytes' again, which will consume extra quotas during the migration process, since they are only reverted after finishing the migration (cancel/complete/start error). So, if the user doesn't have these quotas, the migration will fail here.
One alternative would be to modify quotas 'reserve' method to support quota reservatiopn for share-type type only.
The sum of the quota scoped to each share type should anyhow be equal to the quota not scoped to a share type - so I think this is fine
Ack

I'm not sure about user_id. Should the quota be attributed to the original creator of the share (which is done here) or to the performer of the migration (which would mean to not pass the user_id and use the context instead)?

i agree with Carlos, the new share must in the same project with source share(since end user can't choice share type not available to him), if soruce share and dest share in different pool, source project should consume quota. if in the same pool source project no need to consume quota.
Done

I'd say no, unless the owner of the share changes as soon as we start the migration (which currently does not happen).

1. User creates a share - the share will have user_id set as the id of the user that requested the share
2. Admin request the share to be migrated
2.1 A new share instance is requested [1]
2.2 A new share instance is provided
3. We complete the migration
4. Check the share/share instance

Share instances do not contain a user_id field. This field is part of the share, and the share instance will always be related to the source share. So the source share is still related to the share instance even after the migration gets completed. That makes me think we should keep consuming quotas for this specific user id. Otherwise, migrating a share would also mean changing owners.

I understand the retype scenario, but let's think thorough it:
When retyping, the new type can contain different extra specs, and even though the share would be in the same pool, the backend could not be capable of just acking the change and adding the new capabilities to the share. In that case, they would need to create a new share, move the data and then follow the normal migration workflow. If we just ignore this fact here, two instances will be created and it will end up in only half of the quotas being actually consumed.
We can not foresee what all of the backends are capable of doing or not.
So it's better being safe and leaving the quotas here while the entire migration do not occur than leave unconsumed quota.
It wouldn't be that big of a problem if the user hits into a quota exception, they'd need to contact their administrator, and I believe we already had this discussion in the past for this change :)

This retyping scenario is a good one to think about. I think in this case we would need to switch transfer the quota consumiption (undo the allocation from the source and do the allocation to the dest immediately).

diskimage_builder/elements/cloud-init-gr.message:
So this *likely* needs to also indicate the way this will fail. If the partition structure is different due to the underlying device when the OS boots.

Example: Create image anticipating without LVM thinking all local storage is NVMe devices. Machine is deployed, however the image is written to a fibre channel device, or a SAS/SATA SSD controller. The device names supplied will just not work, and that is a limitation which should be communicated. In depth knowledge of what the deployed machine will look like is needed for this is needed.  A better, albeit way more complex path would be to allow a user to define filesystem mount points, and have a script populate it upon first boot before cloud-init starts.
